summary: This is a peer-reviewed psychological science article titled 'Long-Term Memory in Adults Exposed to Childhood Violence: Remembering Genital Contact Nearly 20 Years Later'. It presents a longitudinal study examining the accuracy of adults' memories for documented childhood genital contact experienced during a forensic medical examination. The study finds that almost half of the adults remembered the contact, with child sexual abuse history and greater depression predicting greater memory accuracy. This document is a research article titled 'Remembering Genital Touch' from the journal 'Applied Cognitive Psychology'. It presents a study examining adults' long-term memory (after nearly 20 years) for documented genital contact experienced during a childhood medical examination. The study analyzes factors like age, gender, depression, and child sexual abuse history as predictors of memory accuracy. This document is a section of an academic research article titled 'Remembering Genital Touch' published in a psychology journal. It reports on a longitudinal study examining adults' memories of a forensic anogenital medical examination they experienced as children approximately 20 years earlier. The study analyzes factors like child sexual abuse history, gender, psychopathology, and prior interviews on long-term memory accuracy and suggestibility for abuse-related events. This document is a reference list from an academic article, likely a literature review or research paper, focusing on the psychology of memory, trauma, and child sexual abuse. It contains no direct information about the Epstein case, individuals involved, or specific events related to it.

events.title: Time 1 Forensic Medical Examinations
events.description: Children suspected of maltreatment were removed from homes and placed in a forensic hospital unit (Under the Rainbow program) for evaluation, where they underwent a standardized anogenital examination as part of a 5-day investigation.

events.title: Time 2 Adult Memory Interviews
events.description: Researchers located and interviewed 30 of the original participants as adults (ages 23-36) about their memories of the childhood forensic medical examination involving genital contact.

events.title: Article Revision Accepted
events.description: The academic article 'Long-Term Memory in Adults Exposed to Childhood Violence: Remembering Genital Contact Nearly 20 Years Later' was accepted for publication after revision.

events.title: People of the State of Michigan v. Lawrence Gerard Nassar
events.description: Historic prosecution case cited as an example where genital touch during medical exams was the alleged crime.

events.title: State of California v. William Ayers
events.description: Historic prosecution case cited as an example where genital touch during medical exams was the alleged crime.

events.title: Time 1 Forensic Medical Examination
events.description: Children suspected of maltreatment underwent a forensic medical examination at a specialized hospital unit, which included an anogenital exam.

events.title: Time 2 Memory Interview
events.description: The original study participants, now adults, were contacted for an unexpected memory interview via phone by unknown researchers to assess their long-term memory of the childhood exam.

locations: Chicago (where participants grew up and the Under the Rainbow program was located)
keyFacts: The study found that almost half (approximately 50%) of adults remembered documented genital contact from a forensic medical examination they experienced as children nearly 20 years earlier.
A history of child sexual abuse and greater depression in adulthood were predictors of greater memory accuracy for the genital contact.
No participant falsely reported chargeable offenses that did not occur, even when such offenses had been falsely suggested in a childhood interview.
The research was conducted to address legal and scientific questions about the accuracy of long-term memory in historic child sexual abuse cases.
The sample consisted of 30 participants who were 4-17 years old at the time of the exam (Time 1, 1990s) and 23-36 years old at the follow-up interview (Time 2, 2012-2014).
The study found that 43% of adults correctly reported documented genital touch from a childhood medical exam after nearly 20 years, while 50% said 'don't know' and 7% incorrectly denied it.

A history of child sexual abuse (CSA) was a significant predictor of accurately reporting the childhood genital contact in adulthood, even after controlling for other factors like frequency of discussion.
Greater depression symptoms in adulthood were associated with greater memory accuracy in answering specific questions about the anogenital examination.
Males were more likely than females to have a 'lost memory' of the entire hospital unit visit and to make more omission errors in their reports.
The research uses documented medical genital contact as an analogue to study memory accuracy for events relevant to historic child sexual abuse prosecutions.
A significant proportion of adults accurately recalled documented genital touch from a forensic medical exam experienced approximately 20 years earlier in childhood.
Adults with a history of child sexual abuse were more likely to accurately report the genital touch, regardless of gender.
No participant falsely reported highly inappropriate, legally chargeable acts (e.g., being hit or kissed by the doctor/nurse) that had been suggested in childhood interviews, even after 20 years.
Some participants were suggestible to plausible, schema-typical abuse-related acts (e.g., doctor taking clothes off) when asked in specific or misleading questions during the adult interview.
The study sample largely consisted of African Americans who grew up in poverty in a large U.S. city and were involved in a child maltreatment investigation in the 1990s.
The document is purely an academic reference list for a psychological study.
It cites numerous studies on memory, trauma, and child sexual abuse, but none are specific to the Epstein case.
The content suggests the parent article may have been about the reliability of memory in legal contexts involving abuse.
No named individuals from the Epstein case appear in this text.
This chunk contains no case-specific facts, only general psychological research citations.
